intro.title: Welcome to the Decompression Calculator
intro.description: This guide will help you understand how to use the application to safely plan your dives. The calculator uses the B√ºhlmann ZHL-16C algorithm with Gradient Factors to calculate decompression profiles.

step1.title: Access the Calculator
step1.description: From the home page, click the "Start Planning" button to access the decompression calculator.

step2.title: Choose Your Mode
step2.description: Select Simple mode for a single-depth dive, or Advanced mode for multi-level dives with multiple gases.

step3.title: Enter Your Parameters
step3.description: Fill in the required fields (depth, time, gas) and adjust the Gradient Factors according to your desired level of conservatism.

simpleMode.title: Simple Mode
simpleMode.description: Simple mode is ideal for constant-depth dives with a single gas mixture.

depth.title: Depth
depth.description: Enter the maximum depth of your dive (1-100 meters). Use the slider to adjust easily.

bottomTime.title: Bottom Time
bottomTime.description: Time spent at maximum depth in minutes (1-200 minutes).

gasMix.title: Gas Mix
gasMix.description: Choose from predefined mixes (Air, EAN32, EAN36, EAN40) or create a custom mix.

advancedMode.title: Advanced Mode
advancedMode.description: Advanced mode allows you to plan complex dives with multiple depth levels and gas switches.

multiLevel.title: Multi-level Dives
multiLevel.description: Add multiple dive segments at different depths with specific durations.

multiGas.title: Multi-gas
multiGas.description: Configure multiple gas mixes (bottom and decompression) to optimize your dive profile.

rates.title: Custom Rates
rates.description: Adjust descent and ascent rates according to your preferences.

gradientFactors.title: Understanding Gradient Factors
gradientFactors.description: Gradient Factors (GF) control the conservatism level of your decompression profile. They are expressed as GF Low/GF High.

conservative.title: Conservative
conservative.description: Safer profiles with longer decompression times. Recommended for beginner divers, difficult conditions, or after an extended break.

moderate.title: Moderate
moderate.description: Balance between safety and efficiency. Suitable for most experienced divers in normal conditions.

aggressive.title: Aggressive
aggressive.description: Shorter decompression times but increased risk. Reserved for very experienced divers in optimal conditions.

results.title: Understanding Results
results.description: Once the calculation is complete, you will see several important pieces of information:

totalTime.title: Total Dive Time
totalTime.description: Total duration of the dive including descent, bottom time, ascent, and all stops.

decoTime.title: Decompression Time
decoTime.description: Total time spent at decompression stops.

ndl.title: No Decompression Limit (NDL)
ndl.description: Maximum time you can spend at this depth without requiring decompression stops.

decoStops.title: Decompression Stops
decoStops.description: Detailed list of all required stops with their depth, duration, and gas to use.

gradientFactorsSection.title: What are Gradient Factors?
gradientFactorsSection.intro: Gradient Factors (GF) are a concept developed by Erik Baker to control the level of conservatism in decompression calculations based on the B√ºhlmann algorithm.

whatAreGF.title: Definition
whatAreGF.description: GFs are expressed as two values: GF Low/GF High (e.g., 30/70 or 40/85). These values represent percentages that modify the supersaturation limits tolerated by the B√ºhlmann algorithm.

howTheyWork.title: How do they work?
howTheyWork.gfLow: GF Low: Applies to the first decompression stop (the deepest). A lower value means you start decompression earlier and deeper.
howTheyWork.gfHigh: GF High: Applies to the last stop (usually at the surface). A lower value means you spend more time decompressing before ascending.
howTheyWork.gradient: Between these two points, the GF increases linearly as depth decreases.

examples.title: Practical Examples
examples.conservative: 30/70 (Conservative): Deeper and longer stops. Ideal for cold dives, after a break, or for cautious divers.
examples.moderate: 40/85 (Moderate): Standard balance between safety and efficiency. Suitable for most recreational dives.
examples.aggressive: 50/95 (Aggressive): Shorter and shallower stops. Reserved for experienced divers in excellent physical condition.

impact.title: Impact on your dive
impact.decoTime: Lower GFs = longer decompression times but safer profile
impact.risk: Higher GFs = shorter decompression times but increased risk of decompression sickness
impact.recommendation: It is recommended to start with conservative values and adjust gradually based on your experience.

definition.title: Definition
definition.description: The NDL (No Decompression Limit) is the maximum time you can spend at a given depth without needing to make mandatory decompression stops during ascent.

howItWorks.title: How does it work?
howItWorks.saturation: During the dive, your body absorbs nitrogen (and helium if using trimix). The longer you stay and the deeper you go, the more your tissues become saturated with inert gases.
howItWorks.limit: The NDL is the point where your tissues reach a saturation level that requires controlled decompression to avoid the formation of dangerous bubbles.
howItWorks.calculation: It is calculated in real-time by the B√ºhlmann algorithm by monitoring 16 different tissue compartments, each with different absorption and elimination rates.

factors.title: Factors that influence NDL
factors.depth: Depth: The deeper you go, the shorter the NDL (e.g., 10m = ~200 min, 30m = ~20 min, 40m = ~9 min)
factors.gas: Gas mix: Nitrox increases NDL because it contains less nitrogen
factors.altitude: Altitude: At altitude, NDL is reduced due to lower atmospheric pressure
factors.gf: Gradient Factors: More conservative GFs reduce NDL

practical.title: Practical use
practical.planning: Use NDL to plan no-decompression dives (recreational dives)
practical.monitoring: Always monitor your dive computer which calculates NDL in real-time
practical.safety: Always stay below NDL with a safety margin
practical.multilevel: Multi-level dives allow you to optimize dive time while respecting NDL

introduction.title: The decompression problem
introduction.description: When you dive, your body absorbs inert gases (nitrogen and helium) under pressure. If you ascend too quickly, these gases can form bubbles in your tissues and blood, causing decompression sickness (DCS).

purpose.title: The role of stops
purpose.elimination: Controlled elimination: Stops allow your body to gradually eliminate inert gases dissolved in your tissues
purpose.prevention: Bubble prevention: By ascending slowly and making pauses, you reduce the pressure gradient and prevent the formation of dangerous bubbles
purpose.equilibrium: Tissue equilibrium: Each stop allows different tissue compartments to re-equilibrate with ambient pressure

types.title: Types of stops
types.mandatory: Mandatory stops: Required when you exceed NDL. Not respecting them can lead to severe DCS.
types.safety: Safety stop: Recommended even for no-decompression dives (3 minutes at 5 meters). Adds an extra safety margin.
types.deep: Deep stops: With low GFs, you start decompression deeper, which can reduce stress on fast tissues.

schedule.title: How to read a stop schedule
schedule.depth: Stop depth: Indicates at what depth you must stop (e.g., 9m, 6m, 3m)
schedule.duration: Stop duration: Time to spend at this depth (e.g., 2 minutes, 5 minutes)
schedule.runtime: Runtime: Total time elapsed since the start of the dive
schedule.gas: Gas to use: Which gas mix to use during this stop (important for multi-gas dives)

example.title: Example of reading a profile
example.scenario: Dive to 40m for 25 minutes with Air (21% O‚ÇÇ)
example.total: Total dive time: ~45 minutes (including ~14 minutes of decompression)

safety.title: Essential safety rules
safety.never: Never skip or shorten a mandatory stop
safety.computer: Always follow your primary dive computer
safety.backup: Have a backup computer or dive tables
safety.conservative: When in doubt, be more conservative (longer stops)

profileReadingSection.title: How to read a dive profile

introduction.title: Understanding the graph
introduction.description: A dive profile is a visual representation of your dive showing depth as a function of time. It's an essential tool for planning and analyzing your dives.

axes.title: Graph axes
axes.horizontal: Horizontal axis (X): Represents time elapsed since the start of the dive in minutes
axes.vertical: Vertical axis (Y): Represents depth in meters (or feet). Note that 0m is at the top and depth increases downward

phases.title: Phases of a dive
phases.descent: Descent: Diagonal line descending from the start of the dive. The slope indicates descent rate (typically 20m/min).
phases.bottom: Bottom time: Horizontal or slightly inclined line at maximum depth. This is the main phase of the dive.
phases.ascent: Ascent: Diagonal line ascending. May be interrupted by stops (horizontal plateaus).
phases.stops: Stops: Horizontal plateaus during ascent. The longer the plateau, the more important the stop.

information.title: Key information to identify
information.maxDepth: Maximum depth: The lowest point of the profile
information.totalTime: Total time: Total horizontal distance of the graph
information.decoStops: Stops: Number and duration of horizontal plateaus during ascent
information.ndl: NDL moment: Point where the dive transitions from 'no-decompression' to 'decompression'
information.gasSwitches: Gas switches: Markers indicating when to change gas mix

multiLevel.title: Multi-level profiles
multiLevel.description: Multi-level dives have multiple plateaus at different depths:
multiLevel.advantage: Allow you to optimize dive time by progressively moving to shallower depths
multiLevel.calculation: NDL is continuously recalculated based on accumulated nitrogen loading
multiLevel.planning: Require more precise planning but offer more flexibility

practical.title: Practical tips
practical.before: Before the dive: Study the planned profile, identify stops and critical points
practical.during: During the dive: Follow your computer which displays the profile in real-time
practical.after: After the dive: Analyze the actual profile to improve future planning
practical.compare: Comparison: Compare planned profile with actual profile to identify deviations

sacRate.title: What is SAC Rate?
sacRate.definition: SAC (Surface Air Consumption) is your air consumption in liters per minute at the surface (1 bar pressure).
sacRate.calculation: To calculate your SAC: divide air consumed by absolute pressure and dive time.

factors.title: Factors that influence SAC
factors.experience: Experience: Experienced divers generally consume less (better breathing control)
factors.effort: Physical effort: The harder you work, the more you consume
factors.equipment: Equipment: Poorly adjusted equipment can increase effort

cylinderSize.title: Cylinder Sizes
cylinderSize.description: Cylinders are defined by their volume in liters and working pressure in bars.

common.title: Common sizes
common.single12: 12L 200 bar: Standard for recreational diving (2400L of air)

calculation.title: Calculating available air
calculation.example: Example: 12L at 200 bar = 2400L of air at surface

ruleOfThirds.title: Rule of Thirds
ruleOfThirds.description: Divide your air into three: 1/3 for outbound, 1/3 for return, 1/3 reserve.
ruleOfThirds.use: Used in cave and technical diving to ensure a safety margin.

turnPressure.title: Turn Pressure
turnPressure.description: The pressure at which you must start ascending or returning.
turnPressure.calculation: Calculated based on the chosen rule (thirds, halves) and reserve pressure.

contingency.title: Contingency Planning
contingency.buddy: Plan air to assist a buddy in distress
contingency.stress: Add 25-50% for stress and unexpected effort
contingency.deco: Plan extra air for decompression stops
contingency.reserve: Always keep a safety reserve (50 bar minimum)
